name: Anchor with justification
summary: Make a strong proposal (or counter) as a justified anchor tied to objective criteria, then invite their constraints with a calibrated question.
goal: Shift the bargaining range in your favour while staying credible and relationship-safe.
counterparty_guidance: Acknowledge the anchor without accepting the frame; ask for the basis.
Introduce your own benchmark or counter-anchor tied to your objectives.
If the anchor is plausible, trade for a concession before agreeing.
If the anchor is extreme, reframe criteria and narrow the range.

when_to_use: You can cite at least one objective benchmark or criterion.
You want to shape the reference point early.
when_not_to_use: You have no plausible rationale and relationship risk is high.
You are extremely time-pressured and cannot withstand pushback.

prerequisites.remediation: Set objectives in the Strategy Canvas before anchoring.

inputs.label: Anchor value (proposal)
inputs.help: Concrete proposal (number/term) you want to put forward.

inputs.label: Trade options (optional)
inputs.help: Optional items you can offer in exchange.

steps.title: Validate context and prerequisites
steps.instruction: Validate prerequisites, restate the intended move, and identify missing info that would improve execution.
steps.notes: If blockers exist, return remediation instead of artifacts.

steps.title: Execute the strategy
steps.instruction: Generate the required artifacts (drafts, packages, checklist) and run critique rubrics before presenting to the user.

snippets.label: Warm opening
snippets.text: Thanks again for the discussion — I’m keen to find an option that works well for both sides.

snippets.label: Anchor ask
snippets.text: Based on what we’ve discussed, I’d like to propose {ANCHOR_VALUE}.

snippets.label: Justification intro
snippets.text: This is grounded in a few objective points:

snippets.label: Closing calibrated question
snippets.text: How does that align with your constraints, and what flexibility do you have on your side?

branches.label: They counter with a much worse term

recommended_move.instruction: Re-anchor to objective criteria, reject the frame politely, and ask a calibrated question about constraints and decision process.

branches.risk_notes: Do not get dragged into their number without reframing to criteria.

success_criteria: Ends with a calibrated question/next step.
failure_modes: Anchor without rationale in sensitive context.
do_not_do: Do not write your minimum or walk-away in the message.

auto_gates.description: Block sending if explicit minimum/bottom line language appears.

ui.card_summary: Set a defensible reference point with objective criteria.
